Hello. I'd like to begin by thanking you for reconsidering the scheduling of Mitragynine Speciosa. When I discovered the wheels were already in motion for the Kratom ban, I felt somewhat hopeless; now I have a faint glimmer of hope for the future of this plant and those who use it. 

I'm a 28 year old male. I started using Kratom almost a year ago to help me manage my opiate painkiller dependence. I'm legally prescribed Oxycodone for several years now for Fibromyalgia. I've suffered from widespread pain 24 hours a day for the last 14 years of my life. On top of that, I struggle with fatigue from being in pain, anxiety, depression, severe migraines, and insomnia (all stemming from the chronic muscular pain). As if all of these symptoms weren't enough to deal with, I had recently struggled with opiate withdrawals since my prescription would not always last an entire month, or because I wanted to stave off addiction/increased tolerance. 

Prior to using Kratom, I would be in complete misery during these detox days. I would have to spend my days off of work in bed, sick as can be. I could see myself eventually illegally acquiring illicit opiates and becoming an addict if I did not find Kratom when I did. Once I learned how to properly use Kratom, the dread of taking days off from narcotic medication seemed trivial. It alleviated a great deal of my withdrawal symptoms and actually helped with some of the pain and energy issues. 

My medication breaks vary from one day to 10 days, depending on my symptoms. After a one week segment of solely using Kratom, I woke up completely withdrawal free. This is after 4 years of daily prescription narcotic use. Furthermore, my Kratom doses lessened each day. I NEVER would have been able to that on my own, let alone go to work during the cessation process.

Aside from the numerous benefits chronic pain sufferers receive from M. Speciosa, recovering addicts have another maintenance drug to utilize. Suboxone and Methadone are arguably harder to quit than the illicit drugs the person was originally addicted to. These drugs are also prescribed at ridiculously high doses and unnecessarily long periods of time. Kratom does a similar job, if not, a better job as a maintenance drug and with a far less severe impact on the addicts life (this information is from personal experience, experience of friends, and online testimonials). Of course there are more serious cases where Kratom isn't the answer for a certain individual, but I truly believe that would be a minority. 

Mitragynine Speciosa does have medicinal qualities. I understand the FDA needs to isolate a specific compound in order to qualify something as "medicinal," however the spectrum of alkaloids found in this plant benefits many. I cannot see someone using this plant to get "high." I have heard it being compared to prescription opiates. I assure you, as a person who is on a legally prescribed opiate regiment, Kratom does not even come close. It naturally prevents a user from taking too much because at a certain point, the harmless negative effects being to undermine the positive effects. I hardly think being nauseous and a little dizzy can be considered "getting high." 

Finally, scheduling Kratom will cause a great deal of suffering to those who use it regularly to alleviate whatever ails them. Many people rely on this plant to stay off of legal and illegal opiates. By making it illegal, I can guarantee the number of addicts, overdoses, and heroin/fentanyl related deaths will sky rocket across the country. The plant is scarcely known in the United States and can do so much for so many. I think it needs to be publicized, not criminalized. It could become an essential tool in combating the opiate epidemic this country faces. Please do not schedule Mitragynine Speciosa. It will hurt the public, and I know it will hurt me. 

Thank you for your time,
Dominick Peluso

In 2009 I was struck by a car while riding on my bicycle, the driver of the car was intoxicated with alcohol and was a "hit and run" driver. The left side of my body impacted the car, my skull cracked on the hood of the car and my left temporal skull bone was fractured severely. I sustained traumatic injuries in my left neck, shoulder, rib cage,  hip, femur, and knee. My body then fell off of the car and impacted the concrete road, seriously injuring my right side, especially my right hip. I sustained multiple abrasions, lacerations, and bone fractures throughout my body. I would later wake up in the trauma intensive care unit (TICU) at the regional hospital in my state, approximately nine hours after I was struck by the car. 

I had extreme cognitive deficits and was having great difficulty with my short and long term memory, I also developed Broca's Aphasia. This type of Aphasia is a neurological disease that affected my speech, language, and communication abilities, all of which are primarily enabled by the left temporal lobe of the brain. My left temporal lobe was compressed by the inward pressure of the collapsed bone fragments from my depressed skull fracture. My skull's bone fragments came within one millimeter of lacerating a major artery in my brain, which would have almost certainly killed me through hemorrhaging. I spent the next year recovering from my body's injuries and my traumatic brain injury. It took me three months to be able to walk again with the assistance of a walker, then weeks later I could walk with a cane, then unassisted. I spent many months in neurological, physical, speech, and occupational therapy. 

Two years after my trauma and brain injury I was almost fully recovered and had overcome my Broca's Aphasia. I've always suffered from severe persistent asthma however, and in the Fall two years post-injury I was admitted into my local hospital's emergency department for a severe asthma exacerbation related to a bout of bronchitis I developed. My asthma attack took several weeks to recover from and I was prescribed heavy doses of both oral and intravenous corticosteroids to treat my lung tissue and airway inflammation. I was ordered to stay on corticosteroids for many months. 

Unfortunately, a major side effect of the corticosteroids I was given is Avascular Necrosis, which for me, was the vascular occlusion of my left and right femoral heads, the round bone "ball" extension of the upper femur that fits into the "socket" of the pelvic acetabulum. Blood supply was cut off to both my left and right femoral heads over the course of several months from corticosteroids to treat my asthma and inflammation. This lack of blood and oxygen resulted in my left and right femoral head bones dying, they became severely necrotic in their cores. 

Eventually after living with severe chronic pain for yet another year, my right femoral head fractured and collapsed in on itself while I was walking in my home. documents.commentText: Since I turned 14, I've been in excruciating pain and dealt with horrible symptoms, such as heavy and painful periods, horrible cramping, nausea, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, digestive problems, diarrhea, constipation, and much more. It progressed throughout high school and college, and I spent much of that time in pain, sick, and scared. I finally was diagnosed with endometriosis at the age of 22. By that time, I had lost 2 jobs through my illness and lost many relationships, friends and memories and opportunities, and was constantly vomiting or fainting from the excruciating pain. I had my first pelvic surgery at 23 in July of 2015, and only 2 months later, relapsed back to all the same pain and symptoms. In the fall of 2015, I began runnng a Congressional campaign (most of the time from a bed or couch because the pain was so intense), and something needed to be done about my pain in order for me to keep working. I was put on Dilaudid, 4 mg every 4-6 hours. I took the entire 4 mg the first dose, and it had such a strong effect on me that I was slurring on the phone when I called my fiancee to come get me from work. I was comatose the rest of the day. The next day, I took 2 mg, and still was too dizzy to even walk straight. I continued taking 1 mg every 6 hours, and did so for a month until my 2nd surgery in January of 2016. My pain was barely managed, and I still could barely handle the side effects. After taking 1 mg of Dilaudid every 6 hours or so for 5 weeks, I went through horrible withdrawal for 5 days; my head pounded, my heart raced, I sweated, vomited, and was so dizzy I couldn't walk. I had a glorious 8 months of remission after my last surgery, but as of September 2016 relapsed into the most debilitating, excruciating, oppressive pain in my back, my hips, my abdomen, my legs, my ovaries, and all the symptoms to go along with it. I was put on Tramadol to help me get through the day at my fast-paced, intense job. It didn't really do anything for me, but gave me so many side effects and an overall unwell feeling. Luckily, one of my fellow endometriosis sisters told me about kratom. I started taking it in October for pain relief, and it has been the biggest blessing of my life. It gives me a solid 6-7 hours of no pain and consistent energy, and I am allowed to live, unencumbered, as though I don't have endometriosis. The only side effect I have ever had is mild constipation. I stopped taking  Tramadol immediately after trying kratom, and have been managing my pain better than ever before in my life. It has given me my life back. I am able to work, play, create, explore, enjoy my life, go full out. If I lose the ability to take kratom, I will return to a shell of my current self; depressed, hopeless, worn down by pain, unable to accomplish a fraction of what I need/want to every day, unable to keep a job, unable to be the fiancee I want to be, unable to be there in the way I want to for my family. Losing kratom would give me the choice between debilitating pain and pain pills that either don't work well, make me feel very ill, or threaten me with addiction. Please do not take away my hope; for the rest of my life, I will be having surgery, going through remission, and relapsing, and starting the process over. If I don't have the pain relief and wellness kratom offers, my life will be cut drastically short, whether judging by productivity and quality alone, or by the harsh side effects of prescription pain pills, which I will avoid unless absolutely necessary. Please don't take away my choice to care for my health in the way that is most effective. Please don't subject me to a life of pain and torture. Please don't take away my hope and potential and possibilities. Please don't mute who I am, who I will become if allowed. Please don't take away my health or my hope.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jessica Lacey and I am a licensed psychotherapist. I have suffered from chronic myofascial pain and a severe, intractable iliopsoas spasm in my hip since I was 19 years old. An avid hiker, four years ago I contracted Lyme disease and ehrlichiosis and spent a week in the hospital. Though I made a full recovery, my immune system has not been the same, and my chronic pain has worsened considerably. I employ a holistic approach to managing my pain, which includes physical therapy, trigger point injections, a TENS unit, meditation, and up until five years ago, medication. In 2011, I discovered kratom and ever since I began using it, I have had almost zero need for muscle relaxants and narcotic pain medication. With two to three moderate doses of kratom per day, I am able to function at my highest level; I finished graduate school, I have an internship as well as a job, and in my spare time I hike and garden and am working on building a nonprofit to help trauma survivors access mental health care. Without kratom, I will either have to give up my functionality or return to using pain medication. This is my greatest fear come true. 

Thousands of people like me have derived tremendous health benefit from using kratom in moderation to relieve chronic pain, depression, anxiety, allergies, and to treat opioid dependence as a substitute for suboxone or methadone.

In contrast to the rampant and factitious rumors that kratom is the new heroin, kratom is an herb native to Southeast Asia, related to the coffee plant. It is neither opioid nor opiate, nor is it related to marijuana. In low doses, it is mildly stimulating, much like caffeine, and in higher doses it is slightly sedating and helpful with pain. While the active chemicals in kratom do bind weakly to opioid receptors in the brain, they are also partial agonists, and do not produce the euphoria caused by classic opiates and opioids (e.g. heroin and oxycodone). Active chemicals in chocolate, cheese, and human breast milk all bind to opioid receptors, as do commonly available over-the-counter remedies like dextromethorphan; yet none of these substances are cause for alarm. 

Unfortunately, the rationale for emergency scheduling of kratom is based on unfounded assumption and buzzword hysteria. Kratom is not equivalent to heroin at all; heroin is eventually metabolized into morphine in the body. Many commercially available and commonly prescribed opiates are converted to even stronger morphine metabolites (hydrocodone and oxycodone in particular). Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, the active chemicals in kratom, are not, and do not have a close chemical relation to morphine. 
The DEA references 15 kratom-related deaths; however, I find myself unable to locate a single instance of toxicity in a user that ingested solely kratom. The ones I was able to locate are instances of polysubstance use, which is an entirely separate issue as the presence of other psychoactive drugs renders the assessment of kratom as a deadly drug to be entirely inaccurate. I also confess that I'm quite confused as to the proportionality of the DEA's reaction: the CDC's study of alcohol poisoning deaths in Massachusetts between 2010 and 2012 showed 11.9 deaths per million. Caffeine is the most common addiction in the country and produces withdrawal symptoms upon cessation. Nicotine is an unscheduled psychoactive substance demonstrated to be addictive, and smoking tobacco is known to be causative for numerous forms of cancer. What's more, the strong opiates in Schedule II are behind an epidemic of opioid addiction in Massachusetts. Other drugs in Schedule II include methamphetamine, ketamine, and cocaine, as they all have recognized medical uses. Rendering kratom a Schedule I substance effectively says that it has no known medical value and high potential for abuse. 

In light of this, the "emergency" scheduling of kratom is unfounded and actively harmful. At minimum, kratom deserves to be researched and subjected to clinical trials. That will not be possible if the DEA's action is not reversed. Please do this nation a favor and allow for the continued legal, responsible use of kratom so that it can help thousands of people achieve and maintain quality of life in the face of their health issues.

Sincerely, 
Jessica M. Lacey, M.S., LMHC

                                              Kratom. Miracle cure or as safe as eating food? Probably.around the same context. Moderation is the key to the plant being a supplement and not a problem. Much like anything else consumable, the alkaloids can be beneficial or potentially harmful depending on dosage and duration. Much like the difference between a few vitamins versus taking so many that toxicity becomes a problem, Kratom can cause problems. Disclaimer aside, this is my experience. 
   I have a degenerated disc in my back and multiple old nagging injuries which benefit from the use of this substance but I choose to consume it for anxiety and ptsd. Not to be politically incorrect but many justify drug abuse for unjustified reasons. I have had panic attacks lasting from minutes to days my entire life. Not pseudo problems, but true attacks. Heart rate at 160 sitting still, paralyzed and sweating,tunnel vision, followed by extreme fatigue and a depressed state of mind. The battle has been real and the options I have had prior to Kratom were both ineffective and wrought with side effects. Opiates are brutal and there is no arguement and anti depressants have inevitable side effects. Insomnia,bowel issues,impotence are among just a few. It may work well for some but I have yet to know a happy consumer of either and to say the least,I have asked around enough to write at least an article on the consequences of both.
   over a decade ago I hurt my back so bad that I had a hard time even getting out of bed or bathing much less being a functional member of society and trying to work. Doctors invariably prescribed me hydrocodone , methocarbamol, and strong anti-inflammatories. within a few weeks of consumption I was able to overcome the muscle spasm flare ups and function with just mild to moderate pain. I am afraid of damage to my organs with any chemical or drugs so I discontinued use a few times after using the prescribed medication. With each prescription, I stopped using them when the pain was manageable. Overall in a little over ten years I have taken them for a month four times. Each of these durations, it only took a week or so to develop a tolerance as well as a craving for them. I could have become an addict easily but my fear of the drugs kept me from filling the bottles again. Side effects were moderate and consistent. Needle pupils, erratic heart rate, incontinence,impotence,sweating,hot flashes, insomnia, so on. the worst part was coming off of the drugs after just a few weeks and having the typical withdrawal symptoms of opioids that lasted around a week by just taking as recommended by physicians. It almost  ensures another statistic of addiction to begin these prescriptions and that is no secret.
   After my Dad passed I had a hard time dealing with it, 8/30 years old for the first time I tried antidepressants and anti-anxiety medication. Lexapro and Klonopin was prescribed by what I considered to be a good and conservative doctor. He strongly advised counseling and exercise and being proactive and healthy about managing anxiety and depression. That said, I had been doing those things for many months to no avail. I took them for roughly three months and the side effects were.... Ghastly. Basically the same as the medication for pain but with much worse insomnia hands and absolutely conquering impotence. my memory was adversely affected as was my social ability hands I basically became a Zombie. I fell into a depression like I had never experienced before and I am a veteran of the State of Mind. The insomnia was terrible and the overall symptoms were much like an addict coming off of a drug Because that is exactly what it was.
   Que Kratom. for roughly a year I went without any medication or treatment for both physical and emotional duress and everyday is a battle that way. After researching homeopathic and natural remedies to both I discovered mitragyna speciosa. I have been taking as medication for roughly six months now. somewhere around 10 grams a day of plain leaf maeng da and occasionally days with up to 20 grams. thus far it has improved my sleep patterns, my energy levels, my ability to exercise and socially it is night and day. I still have anxiety but it is easily manageable compared. I have studied the withdrawal symptoms of Kratom and wanted to experience them for myself. I must be unbiased and say that the withdrawal symptoms are real. After about 24 hours I was a little restless and felt like I had a cold. day 2 was perhaps slightly worse with not being able to sleep as well. day 3 I was over the hill. I went a total of a week without consumption and was normalized. Throughout the detox I was still able to function and was not even close to the misery from pharmacy options.

This is a comment against the DEA proposal to include kratom (and its components including mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine) in the list of schedule I drugs.

When I first learned of kratom years ago, I never had heard of it, and I researched it online.  I hold a PH. D. in zoology and physiology from a major research university and am retired from a university teaching career of nearly forty years during which, as a zoology professor, I taught such courses as human anatomy and physiology, genetics, physiology, and embryology.  I am confident that my education, my teaching experience, and my familiarity with the research process including publication in peer-reviewed journals provide me with a legitimate background to evaluate research information better than most people.  

Kratom has been investigated at various universities, including research at colleges of pharmacy, and the results of those investigations are very promising.  Kratom has been found, in this research, to relieve symptoms of opioid withdrawal, depression, pain, etc.  NO significant negative side-effects were noted in this research.  The testimonials by those using kratom are nothing short of amazing!!  Im sure (and hope!) that you have seen and heard many of these, but, in summary, kratom has saved lives  literally and figuratively, without endangering any at all as indicated by factual accounts.
In spite of the false claims of the DEA, there are NO reports of substantial negative side effects of the use of kratom!!  Yes, kratom has been found in the bloodstream of some individuals who had died from drug overdoses, but there were much more significant illegal drugs also present that would have been the cause of death rather than the kratom.  Once again, there are NO reports of significant negative side effects of kratom!

In fact, report after report indicate that it is impossible to overdose on kratom, for the ingestion of excess quantities of kratom induces vomiting, eliminating the product from the body!!  One cannot consume kratom in great quantities!!  Consequently, how can one overdose on kratom?????

Also, kratom does NOT produce a high!!  Yes, it does relieve depression and anxiety in some individuals, resulting in an improved mental state  simply a return to normality!!  If this is a high, then those of us requiring no medication for psychological problems must be high all of the time!!  Absolutely ridiculous!!!

Testimonies, one after the other, demonstrate that kratom has allowed great numbers of people to return to their normal lives.  I read of one mother who was so crippled by fibromyalgia that she had been bed-ridden for months, totally unable to care for her young family.  Her husband learned about kratom, and, the day after she took her first dose, she was able to prepare breakfast for her family for the first time in months!!  I have read (and have seen videos of) testimonies from U. S. military veterans suffering from PTSD and/or physical injuries suffered while serving our great nation  who credit kratom with saving their lives, often literally.  One such veteran actually recorded at least two videos, one while he was using kratom and one after he no longer could purchase kratom after the DEA actions this fall.  In the second video in which he no longer was using kratom, his body was wracked with twitches and what might be interpreted as mini-seizures  whereas, when he was using kratom, no such symptoms were apparent at all.

It appears that several pharmaceutical companies are preparing to market active components of kratom in the near future.  It is apparent that the pharmaceutical lobby is acting in Washington and our state capitols to eliminate access to kratom in order to increase the profits of these companies.

How many lives of our families and friends are we going to allow to be sacrificed for the sake of pharmaceutical profit????

Finally, it is true that one problem with the sale of kratom is its availability in retail outlets such as head shops and truck stops.  Evidence indicates that the kratom sold in such sources often has been dosed with synthetic drugs to induce effects that will result in repetitive sales to customers. This most likely has contributed to legislation in some states that included kratom along with synthetic marijuana and bath salts as banned substances.  It would be very easy to eliminate kratom sales at such retailers and limit sales to businesses that deal exclusively or almost exclusively in kratom, and a number of these (or all?) are internet vendors.  It would be relatively simple to check the kratom sold by this much smaller number of vendors to assure the sale of pure kratom products.

Lives can be restored and be saved (literally) by the continued availability of kratom!!!

Dr. Michael L .McMahan, Ph. D. (Age: 70)
Professor of Biology Emeritus - Union University
Jackson, TN

Hello, my name is Patti King. I am a part-time field merchandiser. I'm writing to ask that Mitragyna Speciosa, aka kratom, not be placed on the schedule 1 list of illegal drugs that have no medical value.

I suffer from chronic pain syndrome due to a rollover car wreck in 2005, which caused neck injuries (2 herniated discs) that were not treatable with surgery, and did not respond to physical therapy. It was treated with hydrocodone and muscle relaxers. At the time I lived in Texas.

Upon moving to New York State in 2013 I discovered that doctors in this state will not prescribe narcotics. My condition was not deemed severe enough to warrant them. I'll admit it was probably for the best overall, but it's still hard to hear that nothing can be done and I will have to live this way for the rest of my life. They all say "just go home and take ibuprofen,"

About a year and a half ago I read an article about kratom. I researched it, and decided to try it. I have been taking it since. My pain is diminished greatly, and some days eliminated entirely. I have insomnia and RLS as a result of the constant pain. I now sleep much better with taking kratom regularly. The RLS has virtually disappeared. Also, many years ago I was diagnosed with Seasonal Affective Disorder, a chemical imbalance where the pineal gland does not produce enough serotonin during northern winters when the lack of sunlight and cold prevents us from having enough sun exposure to our skin. I have severe depressive episodes during winters. Thanks to kratom, I can deal with these and all my symptoms more easily. 

I also have 3 daughters (ages 25, 33, and 35) who have scoliosis and various immune system issues. One has Behcet's Syndrome. Another has psoriasis. The youngest has the worst scoliosis, and only grew to be 4'8' tall. All suffer from at times debilitating pain, which taking kratom has helped. We're not looking for a "legal high", we simply want relief from our various symptoms. I'm thankful to have found one with the apparent level of safety that this herb provides. It's wonderful to experience the relief it provides, and realize after several hours of work (merchandising can be strenuous) that I still don't hurt.

Please don't take this away from me, and millions like me. I agree that some sort of regulation by the FDA is warranted, for the safety of people from unscrupulous vendors. The ones who are honest should be allowed to continue to provide their product. Please take this to heart and allow us the right to use this herb that helps us so much.

Thank you.

Sincerely,
Patti A King

Good evening. 

Hello. I am writing to you in order to make my opinion on "kratom" known. I have utilized this leaf (which I order whole or in powder form) and consuming it as tea or in smoothies for three (3) years now. I originally decided to try it when my tough physical training schedule caused me to have severe muscular pain lasting for days and rendering me unable to walk up and down stairs. Kratom worked wonders for me in that regard, but it also alleviated my social anxiety and as a result I started dating again and met the woman who would become my wife (we were married in October of 2016). I wanted to stress a few points that I don't often see made:

1. Kratom has never rendered me incapable of performing ANY activity. I routinely drive, type proposals, create graphics for government contracts - including DoD and DHS - and I have given presentations after consuming kratom. It is, to me, the most effective treatment for pain that also provides a slight pep similar to caffeine, but without the jitters. I recently learned that it is a relative of the coffee plant, which convinces me that it should be cultivated and regulated/taxed rather than prohibited. 

2. I have several friends to whom I have recommended kratom for things such as migraines, hangovers (yes, sometimes adults do drink too much) and anxiety. Every one who has tried it has stated that it was effective, and none of them have become "addicted" or even started using it regularly.  In its leaf or powder form, kratom is no "drug of abuse" - but like anything, including caffeine, alcohol or even common kitchen spices like nutmeg, any substance can be abused or converted to more powerful, unnatural versions.  However, even the so-called "extracts" of kratom, which I have tried but not particularly liked, are not likely to cause any responsible adult to become an "addict" or to overdose. It simply isn't possible in my own admittedly anecdotal experience to consume standard or "extract" kratom in sufficient quantities to induce much more than vomiting, followed by feeling standard effects of the substance - slight peppiness and alleviated pain.  In summary, this just isn't a habit forming substance in the same way that most drugs currently scheduled by the DEA can be. 

3. I am concerned that the DEA originally decided to simply place kratom on the most prohibitive schedule and to do so based on somewhat dubious or non-public sources. I would, however, be comfortable if - after the period of comment and evaluation has passed - the DEA decided to schedule kratom extracts or treatments of the plant such that the product or the solution which resulted is not available to persons younger than 18 or 21 except by prescription from a medical doctor/physician.  The regulatory and enforcement framework for this type of restriction may be difficult to implement, however. But the leaf itself or the powder form of pure kratom simply does not belong on any type of law enforcement list. I understand that some states have succeeded (and some have failed) in prohibiting kratom, but in each of these cases there was a representative legislative process under which this was accomplished and there is a transparent, legislative process by which it can be amended or reversed in the future. 

In almost any case, other than for the most dangerous street and designer drugs, I am for regulation and taxation. I don't want the DEA to lose focus on its core mission of protecting the American public from actual drugs with dangerous precedents and I also don't want to push botanicals like kratom into the black market where the drug cartels of Mexico and other criminal organizations become the primary vectors of entry for prohibited items or substances that people will attempt to obtain regardless of prohibitionist policies. I also am extremely uncomfortable with the thought of jailing otherwise law abiding, tax paying American citizens who contribute in almost every phase of society because kratom has provided them with a miracle cure of sorts. 

Finally, I think that research organizations and pharmaceutical companies should be able to study this important plant and placement on the DEA schedule (especially I and II) makes this (as a matter of intent) nearly impossible. 

Thank you for this opportunity to express my concerns regarding what is a very important matter to me personally as well as to many, many other people - some of whom face crippling addictions to drugs and pharmaceuticals which kratom has seriously helped them break. 

Sincerely,

-CC

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a family physician practicing outside Burlington,Vermont.  In our state, as in the entire country, there is a significant problem with narcotic abuse and diversion which has lead to a backlash against the treatment of chronic pain in the medical community.  The problem is that, for pain of significant severity, there are very few effective alternatives to narcotics. Independent of the concern for abuse and diversion there are many well known limitations to narcotics for chronic pain.  These range from constipation to somnolence to respiratory depression.  Add to this the issue of dependence and tolerance (not to be confused with addiction) and narcotics, even without diversion and abuse, are a very imperfect solution.

Several years ago the state of Vermont initiated its medical marijuana registry.  At it's inception I was pretty apprehensive of a flood of patient with "glaucoma" wanting onto the registry for dubious reasons.  There were some of those, which had to be deflected/redirected, but also there have been many success stories.  I have been gunuinely surprised of the effectiveness for many, even patients quite resistant to the idea, but desperate enough for pain control to try it.  Like narcotics, it is not a perfect solution, but a useful tool for some.

I have only had one patient, to my knowledge, try Kratom.  His experience was quite positive, but that hardly represents meaningful evidence of its benefit.  I actually know very little about Kratom and have no misconception that it is some sort of panacea.  But we have few tools for the treatment of intractable pain and those tools are quite flawed.  I think it essential not to close the door on anything that might prove to be one more potential tool in the treatment of chronic pain.  Should Kratom lack the side effect of respiratory depression, that alone would be an incredibly important safety benefit over narcotics.  

My understanding is that a DEA schedule I substance is one with no therapeutic potential.  While, to my limited understanding, the evidence for the potential benefit of Kratom is weak and anecdotal,  there is equally weak evidence of its extreme risk.  There is no risk free medication, or for that matter, substance.  There have been adverse reactions and even deaths due to an excess of antihypertensives, insulin, Tylenol, and even water.  The absence of risk is an illusion.  The question of benefits from Kratom , however, is still an open one.  Given this, it would seem incredibly premature to classify Kratom as DEA schedule I, drastically limiting potential for research.

In short, my hope is that Kratom be left open to research of both its risks and its benefits.  The need for treatment alternatives for chronic pain are far too great to ignore a compound with such potential benefit.  Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W
Dear esteemed comment readers at the DEA,

I am not a radical.  I like to think that I am a fairly balanced person who weighs both sides of issues with equanimity, before I decide where my personal opinion resides.  I am a teacher, one who feels a strong need to make a positive difference in those who take my classes.  And now I feel the need to make a difference by standing up for what I believe is a balanced way of looking at the herbal supplement kratom and to reconsider the decision to prohibit it.

Does kratom have a beneficial place in our society or are we all better off by blocking people's access to it by classifying it as a Schedule 1 drug on the same level as LSD and methamphetamine?  Shouldn't that depend on how many people have found that they really couldn't function in society without it vs. the number of people who have been harmed and even killed by it?  The truth is, there are thousands upon thousands of people in our country who need kratom in order to relieve the debilitating pain that they suffer because it is as effective as opiates for this purpose and much less harmful to the body, if at all.  In addition, to the best of my knowledge, no one has died exclusively because of taking kratom, but rather because they mixed it with alcohol, barbiturates and other substances.  

Another benefit of kratom is relief from anxiety disorders.  For those who have extreme anxiety when in social situations, kratom has been a godsend.  It has allowed them to interact with others and not collapse emotionally or isolate themselves.  For those individuals who suffer from anxiety, kratom is priceless and irreplaceable.  Prohibiting it would be injurious to their health and wellbeing.  

Opiates are far more dangerous to ingest and far less effective for anxiety disorders.  For this reason, kratom occupies a unique place in the natural supplement market and in my opinion should not be pushed under the legal carpet by prohibiting it and thus forcing it into the black market.  If anything needs to be done, I think it would be reasonable to limit it to those 18 and older and do some quality control on it to ensure that people are buying a product that is pure and unadulterated.  That, in my opinion, would serve the greatest good.

As a country, I would like to think that one of our goals is to allow as many people as possible to be productive members of society.  If you classify kratom as a schedule 1 drug, in my opinion you will make it harder for thousands of honest, tax-paying citizens to be able to perform their duties and maintain their employment due to overwhelming pain and/or crippling anxiety.  Please reconsider the ban on kratom, for the greatest good of all concerned.  

Thank you for your time and consideration,

Kurt Kemp

We can provide the public with warnings about the side effects and educate them about usage and dosage, but ultimately their health, body, and actions are fully under their own control and their own decisions.

My wife and I are both highly educated professionals - in no way connected to any sort of "down and out drug community." 	Given the circumstances, I feel strongly enough to comment on this issue and voice my opposition of the DEAs quickly arriving Intent to Schedule the alkaloids, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, contained in kratom (Mitragyna speciosa). Kratom is a member of the coffee tree family and similarly mild in effect. If the scheduling were to succeed, the Kratom plant would be rendered a Schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value, lumped in with devastating hard drugs like heroin. That is very far from the truth. Kratom has a long history of medicinal uses and continues to help millions of people today, including myself! It is a fantastic remedy for a plethora of ailments, ranging from physical, as well as psychological, conditions including chronic pain, anxiety, depression, PTSD, but maybe most strikingly, it is a miracle remedy for opiate addiction- an epidemic in our country currently. Ive personally been diagnosed with Social Anxiety Disorder and Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, which are emotionally crippling conditions in themselves. It has affected my family relationships, jobs, and every aspect of my life, which certainly contributes to being partial to opiates. Ive tried many medications but Ive found a system that works. Kratom is a prime factor in my psychological health, but its not just my emotional health that benefits from kratom, as Ill explain. A major concern of mine is that we would be losing out on future research of this versatile plant and I and many others will lose their saving grace. There have already been studies determining that kratom is an effective painkiller without the potentially deadly respiratory-depression that comes along with opioid medications (such as OxyContin, Dilaudid, etc), the main culprit in overdoses everyday.  People are unnecessarily dying and there is a better option that deserves our attention.
	Several years ago, while playing with my little girl I injured my back. It was the most excruciating pain Ive ever felt in my life. I had to be carried down the stairs and into the hospital and ended up having to use a walker to assist me for the following weeks. They initially gave me Fentanyl in the E.R. followed by other medications including Vicodin and muscle relaxers. Eventually, I developed a dependence to using opiate drugs. It began to affect my ability to work and to interact with my family. It was like my daughter didnt know who I was anymore. Once I knew I had to stop using these drugs, I looked to treatment programs like methadone clinics and Suboxone doctors. These prescribed substitute drugs were as difficult, if not more so, to become abstinent from than the original meds! If the meds werent available, I looked to street drugs. After trying rehab and still desperate for an answer, I began to search the internet and found that some people had positive results with some kind of tea-like leaf called Kratom. After picking some up from a local shop, I made the decision to try it instead of the synthetic alternatives with their myriad of side-effects, including drowsiness and being emotionally distant to my friends and family. The effects were nearly imperceptible but I realized I didnt feel the usual withdraw symptoms like I did when attending opioid maintenance programs. I needed less and less Kratom daily and in a relatively short period of time, I wasnt dependent on any chemicals, whatsoever! Somehow this herbal powder gave me my freedom back and made me feel normal without prolonged withdrawal effects. Now, I do not use any opiates or other drugs and its thanks to kratom. Kratom was virtually free of side effects and very mild, similar to other herbal supplements you can obtain at the grocery store.  Unlike other over-the-counter meds like Aspirin, ibuprofen or Tylenol, kratom doesnt cause any issues with the stomach or liver. I honestly dont know where my life would be at had I not found it. It saved me.
	With the opiate/opioid epidemic sweeping our country and overdoses ever-rising, we need a safe alternative to pharmaceutical painkillers and Kratom is that better option. Im certain opiate use and overdoses will continue to rise even higher if a ban is placed on Kratom and even I, might become a casualty. With a job, daughter, and family that needs me, I know the standard of my life wont be the same without kratom. I humbly ask you to reconsider the scheduling of kratom.
	Thank you so much for taking the time to hear my story!

documents.commentText:
Sir or Madam:

As a professional who treats individuals with substance abuse problems and co-occurring mental illnesses, it is rare for me to support non-research-based treatments or supplements.  While I do not recommend kratom for my patients at this point, I have, recently tried it in order to manage my own chronic migraine pain, and to good effect.  

I am a true cynic, but with cautious and self-educated use (as much as is possible with limited research), I have been able to significantly manage the pain of chronic migraine days (8-14 days/month) without resorting nearly as often to hydrocodone or other Schedule 1 painkillers I previously used.  This allows me to be a contributing member of society, not home in bed sedated as with the opiates I used to take, and the phernegan it took to keep them down.  I am a law-abiding citizen, and do not use alcohol or drugs for recreation.  Should kratom become illegal I will no longer use it, and return to the medications prescribed by my physician.

It would also more easily allow the needed medical research to be done to further focus on the specific chemicals in kratom that work to develop more targeted medications.  Thus far both case study and published research http://www.cato.org/blog/addiction-problem-case-kartom indicates it does NOT appear to have the same addictive potential as other narcotic drugs. 

The legislation, as it currently reads, would place Kratom and its alkaloids in the most severe scheduling category, schedule I.  Making this plant and its constituents schedule I, effectively makes it impossible for legitimate researchers to discover and develop valuable medicines from Kratom that could benefit the lives of millions, and possibly replace the much-more-deadly opium-based drugs.

Like almost all supplements, avid promoters would have you believe it is a panacea.  I am sure it is not.  However, it appears to have benefit in treatment of pain, drug (legal or other) withdrawal, and possible immuno-modulation properties. A brief search in any scholarly database will present hundreds of peer reviewed studies and clinical trials that can attest to the medical POTENTIAL of this plant.

Of course there are side effects, and again I note that making it a Shedule 1 drug will eliminate the ability to effectively and readily explore the risks as well as the benefits of this substance and it's active substrates.

With the opiate crisis, I understand the desire to clamp down on anything that could possibly add to those terribly sad deaths.  Not having safe and legal ways to manage chronic pain are what have driven many to illegal street drugs and subsequent death.  

A more reasonable and thoughtful approach to kratom could certainly be developed than slamming it into Schedule 1 without exploring the possible benefits. Please re-consider placing this plant in the most severe scheduling category and consider reasonable legislation that would allow for those over age 18 to use it, perhaps as marijuana has been legalized, taxed, and monitored for quality in several states. This is not a substance that needs to have a war declared on it; but one that can be safely studied and utilized by the medical community.

Thank you for your consideration,

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA and others concerned-

My name is Jennifer Blair.  Im a 44 year old woman living in Powell, Ohio.  I would like to give you a brief history about myself.  Im a college graduate and I have been a law abiding citizen my entire life.  I was in media for almost 20 years and was successful in my career.  I was a very active person, paid my taxes and paid into the Social Security system.  Then, in 2010 my life as I knew it ended when I became ill with the Epstein-Barr virus, psoriatic arthritis and Chronic Lyme Disease, just to name a few of my ailments.  I had to leave my job.  I spent the next four years in and out of doctors offices.  None of my ailments can be cured; only treated.  And I cant treat my psoriatic arthritis because of my Chronic Lyme Disease.  Ive accumulated large amounts of medical debt that I simply couldnt pay because I had no income.  The one doctor I had to see every month was my pain specialist who prescribed me large doses of opiates.  I didnt want to be on opioid medications but they helped me get out of bed and do the very basic chores of bathing and feeding myself and kept me from committing suicide.  Im not trying to be dramatic when I share that information but if youve ever suffered from chronic pain, you are aware of how absolutely depressing it is to live with constant pain. Especially when you have no hope of ever being cured.  All I can do is treat the symptoms and take one day at a time.  Add to being depressed from my illnesses, I wasnt proud of taking pain medications.  Pharmacists and doctors treated me like I was an addict just looking for a fix.  And I was raised in a very conservative family and had very conservative ideas about myself, my life and my work.

In October of 2015, I had to make the choice of giving up my pain management doctor.  His office visits and the costs of my prescriptions became too much.  It was costing me about $1,000. per month.  I knew I was going to begin a very ugly withdrawal when my body stopped receiving the medication.  I panicked.  I called all of my other doctors and explained the situation but they either wouldnt or couldnt help me.  As Ive found out over the years, there arent many doctors who want the repercussions from our government/DEA from helping chronic pain patients by prescribing opiate pain medications.  Its a shame but its the reality of the situation.

My next step was getting myself into a drug treatment/rehabilitation facility.  The waiting list at that time was months.  Like 3-4 months.  Unless I had approximately $4,000. to pay upfront for a private facility, which, of course, I did not.  I wasnt thrilled at the idea of going to a rehabilitation facility because there they take their patients who are addicted to one drug and get them addicted to another drug (Suboxone, etc), but I was terrified to go though the withdrawals which Ive heard can be life threatening.

With the possibility of a rehabilitation facility gone, my only choice left was to buy pain medication from drug dealers or start using heroin, a much less expensive option.  Then, a nurse from one of my doctors office told me about Kratom.  She had a friend that used it to kick her heroin habit.  She told me it was completely natural and convinced me to try it.  I truly believe God sent me an angel in that nurse.  Ive been off opiates since November of 2015 and am doing better than I had ever hoped.  Mentally Im fantastic and Im even working a little more, which is fantastic as Ive been denied SSD twice.  Before you make a decision to make Kratom an illegal drug, I want you to consider a few points:

1)	Kratom is safe.  Its virtually impossible to overdose on it.  Unlike heroin or opiates, the more you take does not equal a better high.  In fact, Kratom doesnt make me high at all.  It is not a danger to our citizens.
2)	There are not enough rehabilitation facilities available for people in need.  By making Kratom illegal, you are forcing an already terrible drug epidemic to become even worse.
3)	There is NO proof that Kratom is dangerous.  People around the world have been using it for centuries, if not thousands of years.
4)	Kratom is the best choice for me and living with chronic pain.  There are thousands of me out there.  Dont take away a natural leaf that has helped so many with pain, PTSD, anxiety and other ailments.

In closing, thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
Hi. I'm a 41 year old caregiver working with both children and elders.  I took kratom long-term, every day, in fairly high doses (1 tbs, 2-3 times a day) consistently for about 3 years.  I started taking it after hearing about it from a friend who let me try some of his.  It helped me immensely with anxiety and depression and energy level.  There were never any bad side effects.  It is both mild and effective, in my personal experience.  I always purchased the pure powder in bulk form from trusted sources, just like an herbal tea.  My family supported me in taking this supplement because they could see that it helped me.

My kratom consumption never interfered with my work, my relationships, or my stability.  On the contrary,  it helped me to be healthier and higher functioning, better able to do my job.  

The only reason I have stopped taking kratom is because I am trying to conceive and I am being extra cautious.  Quitting kratom was easier than quitting coffee, and I stopped taking it 3 months ago and have no cravings of any kind.  I'd like to have the option to take it in the future if I need to.  Alternatives (pharmaceuticals) have never worked as well for my mental health with as few side effects or dangers.

Kratom has been used medicinally in Southeast Asia for thousands of years and has proven in that long period of time to be generally benign.  It helps so many people with chronic pain.  It does not cause respiratory depression or death. At most, it causes nausea/vomiting if someone takes too much (although this has never happened to me).  

If it is made illegal, it seems to me that it would purely be a political move, not one to help people.  Do we really need to further the failed drug war over a mild herbal medicine?  In states where kratom has been banned, opiate use has gone up.  People have died as a result.  If you truly want to protect people, protect this plant as a natural herbal medicine, available in it's pure and natural form.

I ask that you keep kratom 100% legal.
Thank you for considering this comment.

documents.commentText:
I am a 32 year-old white male living in California. I have an Ivy League degree and work in process development in the bio-pharmaceutical industry. I have taken kratom since 2014. These comments are abridged with much concerning the pharmacology of kratom removed as potential trade knowledge.

In 2013 I suffered a traumatic crush injury on my left leg that resulted in rhabdomyolysis, muscular atrophy, full paralysis and a necrotic sciatic nerve. For pain during physical rehabilitation I was prescribed morphine, oxycodone and fentanyl (in succession). After about 18 months, I decided the pain was less severe than the side effects of the drugs and tapered off all opioids. 

Very soon I was suffering from opioid withdrawal, chronic moderate intensity pain due to my limb dysfunction and depression due to my situation. At this point I discovered kratom. It appealed to me because it was derived from a plant, was freely available, and was described as "mild" a "partial-opiate agonist" and for help with "opiate withdrawal and chronic pain."

I started taking prepared capsules at the amount of ~ 4.5g / dose. I found that these doses lasted around 6 hours, which brought my average daily consumption to between 12-14g. At these levels, both the withdrawal from fentanyl patches and the residual pain in my leg were alleviated. 

At the daily doses I was taking there were several side effects: nausea, pain in the abdominal area, vomiting, itching, stimulation, anxiety, sleeplessness and abnormal thought patterns. The negative side effects are dose-dependent and are not necessarily typical opioid side effects. It is not clear which side effects are due to the preparation (nausea and abdominal pain could be caused by the physical consumption of 14g indigestible plant matter daily) and which are due to (un)desirable active alkaloids or other causes.

I found that it was almost impossible to sleep, except at night, when taking kratom. This is the exact opposite of the situation with traditional opiates, where one struggles to stay awake. Again, it is not known if this effect is common, and whether it is due to one of the putative active alkaloids or to one or more of the dozens of other alkaloids present in plant matter. Although I felt that the transit in my GI tract was slower while taking kratom, I did not experience constipation. 

At no point in my two years taking kratom have I felt that I was slipping into unconsciousness unintentionally or struggling to breathe. In the instances that I have "overdosed" on kratom, the most severe effects were anxiety, slightly elevated heart rate and palpitation, nausea, vomiting and over-stimulation. This side effect profile is closer to that of caffeine than morphine. Only once, after about a year of taking kratom on a daily basis, were side effects bad enough to seek a doctor. I went in for abdominal pain, was told to take less kratom, drink water and take more exercise. These interventions were effective. I also had a blood panel done which showed no elevated liver enzyme levels. 

When I heard that kratom was about to be scheduled, I decided to stop taking it. I was extraordinarily fearful of a severe withdrawal syndrome because I had been using it in place of fentanyl. I did a taper over three weeks. The withdrawal syndrome was very mild and more psychological than physical. It was harder to taper off Prozac than to taper off kratom. A month after stopping use, I would state that there has been no long-term after-effects.

As a substitute for opioids and as a treatment for chronic pain and depression, I believe there is substantial evidence that kratom or its active ingredients are effective.

I support regulation regarding GMP manufacture, sourcing, purity and warning labels for kratom. I believe that the powdered plant matter should not be extracted or compounded and should be regulated as a supplement rather than a drug. I also believe sale should be limited to 21+. I believe that it can be habit forming. I also believe that it is a viable, inexpensive and relatively safe substitute for much harder, more addictive and dangerous drugs.

I believe there is potential for the development of pharmaceutical derivatives, which would fall under DEA scheduling requirements. Being in the pharmaceutical industry, I am highly enthusiastic for all new candidate drugs that emerge for intractable problems - such as opioid addiction. I would like to see the potential of this substance developed, rather than destroyed. The DEA and the FDA should work together to ensure a workable solution, including the AKA and other pharma industry representatives.

Thank you for you time.

America is supposed to be the land of liberty and freedom, yet the government chooses to tell us what we can and can't put in our bodies. Greetings,
     I am a 66 year-old retired business woman.  Beginning in 2001, a number of tragic as well as life-threatening events occurred in my life.  Without going into the details, suffice it to say that the amount of stress was intense and unyielding.  The psychological and physical effects resulted in the need to see a number of counselors and psychiatrists, and also a variety of medical doctors including general practitioners, internists, and surgeons.
       From a psychological perspective, I was diagnosed with "compound trauma," and "anxiety disorder."  Every physician that I saw, albeit from a mental/emotional or physical/bodily perspective, recommended Xanax and a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor (SSRI).  While I could tolerate Xanax, I am one of the few people who have an extremely negative reaction to any and all of the SSRI drugs that I was prescribed.  I therefore became increasingly dependent on Xanax.
       Over the course of a decade, the stress took its toll physically resulting in a brain tumor, fibroid tumors in my uterus, and breast cancer.  The surgeries required a concomitant number of pain medications, thus the difficulty in weaning myself off these medications became increasingly challenging.  Because Xanax was so hard to free myself of, I swore to avoid it at all costs and ultimately ended its use entirely, yet the trauma issues had by this time resulted in PTSD.
      About three years ago a friend who was experiencing significant stress recommended Kratom powder.  I was leery due to my previous experiences with Xanax, pain medications, and SSRIs.  What a surprise to find Kratom powder efficacious in treating the anxiety disorder.  The "recommended" dose seems to be about 1-3 teaspoons up to 3 times a day.  I have been able to find relief by using only 1/2 teaspoon twice a day.  Although this is a small dose, it has proven a lifesaver.
      To ensure that I was not getting physically addicted, I have stopped using Kratom a number of times with no adverse reaction: no headaches, chills, fever--in short, the type of reactions incurred when I had attempted to wean myself from traditional pharmaceutical drugs in the past.
      Kratom is the only substance I take.  It has helped so much with anxiety and with high blood pressure that it is the only product that I need to take.  My quality of life has improved beyond what I would have been able to imagine prior to trying Kratom powder.  I am able to sleep at night, perform paying freelance work, and do volunteer work for two organizations.  The thought of going back to those pre-Kratom days is, I trust understandably, most distressing.  Ensuring its legality is extremely important to me as I fear with all of my being the thought of returning to traditional pharmaceutical remedies.
      Thank you for your help in keeping Kratom legal.  It means so much to me.
      With kind regards,
      Donna Koth

documents.commentText:
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, also known as Kratom, Ketum, and some other names, has no business being a schedule I drug. Scheduling it as such would put it in the same category as heroin, which is a dangerous and misleading representation of this plant. While it does remain true that Kratom acts on opiod receptors, it is not the same. I have personal experience with opiods and Kratom. In May, I was in a car accident that left me in an incredible amount of pain, pain that still plagues me to this day. After the accident, my doctor prescribed me 5-mg Hydrocodone with acetaminophen, to be taken every 4 hours for pain. While it did help relieve my pain, it also gave me some horrendous side effects, such as the incapability to make complete bowel movements, irritability, and all I wanted to do was sleep. I began to find myself wanting the pills before it was "time" and would become increasingly angry or sad while I waited. I did not want to become another statistic, addicted to painkillers because I was genuinely in pain. So, I just tried to stop taking them. I found myself struggling to stop. I couldn't sleep, I was incredibly ill, and the depression that ensued was debilitating. That is when I was introduced to Kratom. A friend who had been in a similar (actually worse) accident than me introduced me to Kratom. The plant was a miracle in my eyes. When I drank the tea he had made, it only took 15 minutes for my back pain to subside, and I didn't notice any of the ill effects that I had from the opiods. I was not upset or totally lethargic. The first day I took Kratom was the first day I had felt human since my accident. Now I can wake up and drink this tea, go to work, and function. 
With that being said, there is some controversy around the side effects of Kratom, which are listed on the National Institute of drug abuse's website as: sensitivity to sunburn, nausea, itching, sweating, dry mouth, constipation, increased urination, and loss of appetite. It can be seen that the side effects of Kratom do mirror those of opiods, but that those side effects do not include respiratory depression, liver damage, or death like the pills given to people every day, or the street drugs that are often turned to when the scripts run out. It cannot be denied that these side effects are present in some users, but it can be said that they are infinitely less noticeable while using Kratom vs. opiods. This is important to consider, especially when there are so many stories about people using this plant to distance themselves from opiod problems (which include heroin). It also cannot be denied that there are people who feel "withdrawal" from Kratom, but in every case that I have heard of the withdrawal symptoms are incredibly mild compared to someone who attempts to stop prescription opiods or heroin. In my personal experience there have been days where I either had to go without or even FORGOT to take it. Of course I would notice my pain, but no terrible symptoms like I did when I was trying to stop taking the opiods. Allowing Kratom to be easily accessible could really help with the opiod crisis. This is not just some cry from a personal user hoping to keep this plant available, but a person concerned for all the people who remain functional and clean today because of this plant.
Now that the medical concern has been addressed, it is time to talk about some other concerns when it comes to banning this plant. This plant, a tree native to southeast Asia, provides income to the people who harvest and sell the material. The ban threatens these trees because once that source of income is ripped away from these people, they will most likely turn to palm oil and paper production. This will result in mass clearings of these forests. Withdrawing the ban will leave incentive for these people to maintain the forests. Protecting the forests is of course good for people because it keeps the air clean, oxygenated, and keeps the land from wearing away (due to the root systems), but it is also painstakingly important for the entire ecosystem. These forests that may face annihilation after the ban are also home to species such as the orangutan, elephants, and tigers. There is the argument that deforestation in these areas is illegal, but that did not stop the burning of trees in the area in 2015, when the need for money caused the people to clear land (illegally) to produce palm oil in order to supplement their income. If it happened once before, what would make anyone think that these people would not feel desperate enough to do it again if they faced another hardship when this source of income was taken from them?
I genuinely hope for the good of the people who have found sanctuary in Kratom, for the people who have earned a living harvesting these leaves, and those endangered species, that the sale of this plant remains legal. It would be a great disservice to the world to place Kratom in the Schedule I drug classification.

Dear Sirs and Madams,

I am heartened to hear of the DEA's decision to reconsider their intention to schedule kratom based on public opinion and (also hopefully) evidence of its benign adverse health effects.  We live in a world of reactionary, under-informed, and misinformed public opinion.  The internet is quick to confirm any bias you may be searching for.  There is no harm is slowly down, doing the research, and listening to what the country actually has to say.

I am an MS graduate in Electromagnetics - not pharmacology or biology for sure, but I am an academic nonetheless. I have researched kratom, and I have quite a few colleagues who frequent SE Asia, where kratom can be well likened to cannabis in illegality, public stigma, as well as competition with corporate interests against actual (dangerous) opiates and opiods.

I'd simply like to make a few terse points below:

- There is no credible evidence that there is a viable overdose case for kratom.  The few cases available online and in the news (including the death-certificate cause case) are circumstantial, few, and in many cases multiple substances were found in usage, making it impossible to make good conclusions.  It's not possible to say "There has never been a single case of deadly overdose," but it's also not possible to say that about agreed-harmless items like coffee and cheeseburgers (not to mention alcohol).

- There is no argument for kratom as a gateway drug, and if anything there is the opposite argument, given kratom's opiate-like effects and proven successful tool in aiding opiate/opiod withdrawal.  This plant is arguably part of the solution, and it would be clearly in corporate interest of Pharma (and not the people) to ban it.

- Possibly most-importantly, we have learned a lot from the banning (and step-wise decriminalizing and legalizing) of marijuana.  A LOT of people who are otherwise ethical and moral people were imprisoned for years (to life) for participating in a harmless trade, which provided people with something they desired, and did them, nor anyone else, any significant harm.  Additionally it undermined the legitimacy of the DEA's opinion on what was truly dangerous.  When you have harmless agents like pot (or kratom) on a list next to heroin and meth, it may cause people to think "Well clearly this list is BS.  What other drugs on this list are actually harmless?"

Again I applaud your effort to seek public opinion, and I hope you hold with you decision to leave kratom unscheduled.

Sincerely,
Dave Dieter

My name is Isaiah Bugarin. I am a college student and a former opiate addict. If it was not for the plant known as kratom, I would still be an opiate addict on a collision course with death. For a long period of my addiction, I was completely aware of the course I was taking and where I would end up. The stereotype is that people of my kind are either unaware of their eventual demise, or must be simply too strung out to care. The fact is that I was aware and I did care, greatly. I cared enough to quit more times than I could count. But opiates are not like other drugs; they find a way to suck you back in through ways so novel there appears at times to be a sentience to its deception.

One of these ways is through withdrawal. Withdrawal, being only temporary, seems like it would pose an insignificant challenge for someone with a little dedication. This is not the case, and it is where most of my attempts to quit opiates ended. To say withdrawal is crippling would be a significant understatement. I have had cancer, and opiate withdrawal is the only other experience in my life that has been so painful, so relentlessly tormenting. With relief from this suffering just an opiate away, it seemed there was an insurmountable amount of willpower necessary to push through weeks of withdrawal's abuse. This is where kratom came to my rescue. After dozens of unsuccessful attempts at quitting (with a few half-successful relapses), I decided to try using kratom to taper off opiates. In doing this, I experienced a significant decrease in withdrawal symptoms that made quitting a simple matter of dedication. I quit successfully on my first attempt and haven't touched an opiate since.  

Another way opiates creep their way back into addicts' life is through PAWS (post-acute withdrawal syndrome). The depression and anxiety that accompany a post-opiate life are the reason that many addicts make the seemingly daft decision to relapse. It is this monster that lives inside the addict's head at all times and shouts at random intervals about how nice just one dose would feel. How much better this day would be if I got high. It is a monster that you never truly learn to live with. But with kratom at my side, living with it is more than manageable. Tickling a few of the same receptors that opiates used to flood, kratom provides just enough of a relief to force the monster mute into a cage without giving a recreational high. Kratom is what prevents me from returning to a life of opiate addiction. I wish I could say it was willpower, but the fact is I have tried the willpower only route of abstaining from opiates. Every time ended badly. Now that I have been using kratom to kill the inevitable opiate cravings, I haven't used an opiate in nearly 2 years.

Opiate addicts are not lost causes. They are people who more than anything in the world just want their lives back. All they need is a way, and my experience has shown me that kratom is an unparalleled tool for doing just that. Some in the scientific community have also made note of its potential in this regard. Instead of allowing for further research to help combat the massive opiate problem in this country, the DEA has decided to declare kratom an imminent public health hazard and place it on the Schedule I list of drugs. They are not treating the opiate problem; they are taking away the cure. Not only is this a gross overstep of the DEA's authority, it is going to put tens (if not hundreds) of thousands of people just like myself in a position where they must rely on their notoriously unreliable willpower to keep them from a lifetime of opiate addiction.

Please, give my monster a cage. Keep kratom legal.

Stop interfering in people's self-medication and infringing on their freedom to eat, drink, smoke or  whatever the hell they want. This is none of your business anyway. 

But for the record, there are plenty of reasons in particular why not to make kratom illegal:

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

I am a 31-year old attorney, a husband and father of a small child. All of that is to say I'm not a junkie or an addict or even  someone who has ever set foot in a head shop. 

I also suffer from generalized anxiety disorder. I have tried numerous things to help my symptoms; half a dozen prescription drugs, meditation, exercise, breathing techniques, and all sorts of supplements. Kratom has helped in a way that nothing else has. I have been using it for years now and it has made a big difference in helping me to relax and focus on my life rather than on worries about the future. 

I use it several times a week. I consistently use the same amount and I have taken breaks for weeks at a time with no difficulty. The side effects are minimal, and in my experience kratom, in plain leaf form, is extremely safe. On the few occasions when I've had a little too much, the resulting upset stomach is enough to make anyone stop. Too much plain leaf will make you vomit long before you could ever hurt yourself in any more serious way with it. 

I have researched kratom extensively and the available evidence bears this out. Deaths associated with kratom are rare. Much lower than say, alcohol (which is legal and unrestricted, by the way) or even aspirin (which is also legal and unrestricted and far easier to kill yourself with). The modest number of deaths associated with kratom are all confounded by the presence of (usually high amounts of) other, more dangerous drugs in the body of the deceased. I am not aware of a single death caused by kratom alone without any other more dangerous substance being present. Calling kratom a "public health emergency" is laughable. 

Making marijuana illegal is one of the most pernicious things the Federal government has done to its own people, criminalizing a safe and medically-effective plant for no good reason and leading to the incarceration of thousands who do not deserve to be in jail or have criminal records. Making kratom illegal would be duplicating this same mistake. 

If you ban kratom, you aren't protecting me or anyone else. You are using the force of law to rob people of a helpful and recreational plant for no good reason. You are ruining the livelihood of kratom vendors and threatening those who choose to continue using kratom with prison for a behavior that harms no one. At that point, one must ask oneself which is more dangerous - kratom or the federal government? Only one of the two can ruin your life with a criminal record and a lengthy stay in prison. The other just helps you relax. 

Kratom is a safe, useful, and recreational herb. It should remain unscheduled and should be regulated only to ensure that vendors aren't adulterating it with other substances. If the DEA wants to maintain any thin pretense that it exists to serve the American people then it will honor the evidence and the experiences of so many users and abandon this mad plan to ban a harmless and much-loved plant. Leave kratom alone.

As a psychiatric pharmacy specialist and master of public health I have this comment to make:

To place kratom and associated mitragynine compounds in schedule I is ridiculous. To do so, the DEA should have solid evidence that there is no medical use and high potential for abuse - both of which are lacking in this case (and for most drugs in the CI category). In fact, evidence exists to the contrary. Many report on medical benefits of using Kratom. While it's not without risks (no drug or herbal product is) there is no evidence Kratom should be a CI drug. In the midst of an opioid epidemic in which thousands of Americans are dying annually it is blatantly in the public's worst interest to place a drug like Kratom in a CI category as many use Kratom as an opioid alternative or to ween themselves from opioids. 

The move would perpetuate a broken trend of trying to prohibit drugs or plant products which inevitably creates a black market and associated dangers, people are criminalized for trying to relieve their or others' suffering, legitimate medical research is oppressed by grueling regulatory burdens, and the problem doesn't get better (it gets worse). Please consider rational and evidence-based policy solutions such as harm reduction rather than prohibition which has proven itself to be a failure time and time again. The fact the DEA wants to do this exemplifies to me that they do not care about public health, medical research, or evidence-based policy making. It seems they are motivated mostly by trying to find ways to increase the burgeoning prison population and a status quo of ignorance to drug effects. I can't say much more except it is disgusting and heart breaking this would be proposed.

Thanks for your consideration of this comment in this important decision that will affect the lives of many Americans..

Ben Malcolm, PharmD, MPH
Assistant Professor of Pharmacy Practice
