My name is Garrett. I'm a 24 year old male living in San Diego, CA. I graduated from the University of San Diego in May 2015, and currently work as a front desk agent at Tower23 Hotel in Pacific Beach, CA. I am vehemently opposed to the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, found in kratom, a schedule 1 controlled substances. My stance on the matter is based on the limited available scientific research on kratom, my own philosophical, political, and ethical views, as well as my personal experience using kratom to alleviate physical pain, anxiety, ADHD, fatigue, and trouble sleeping. I first consumed kratom in the fall of 2013 while playing rugby and finishing my undergraduate studies at the USD. At the time, a local restaurant made tea using kratom that they only sold to adults. I happened to try it during exams and quickly noticed how it helped me focus while simultaneously relieving anxiety related to school. The added focus was especially nice because I was diagnosed with ADHD a few years prior and don't particularly like how classic ADHD meds such as Adderall make me feel. Additionally, using kratom lessened the physical pain that resulted from injuries caused by playing rugby, while motivating me to continue exercising in order to stay in shape and continue playing. All that said, what most compels me to voice my opinion on the legality of kratom is the plethora of friends, family, and acquaintances of mine that abuse or have abused prescription pain-killers. The problem has become so common and pervasive that I'd be hard pressed to name someone that I know who's life hasn't been negatively affected in some fashion by prescription opiods. Furthermore, I have personally witnessed several friends kick or lessen substantially the severity of prescription drug habits and/or alcohol abuse using kratom, which thankfully has little or no serious side effects such as respiratory suppression. I, myself, was able to avoid taking prescription oxycontin following a recent surgery for a wrist injury that left me with awful nerve pain. Neither gabapentin nor oxycontin made the nerve pain bearable, but kratom did so effectively without leaving me constipated, lethargic, or foggy-minded. My guess is that many people suffering from chronic pain would be healthier and far more productive members of the work force using kratom rather than prescription opiods. I encourage those interested in the science behind kratom to read the work of Chris McCurdy, a University of Mississippi professor of medicinal chemistry and pharmacology. The Journal of the American Osteopathic Association among other reputable sources easily found online also provide objective, fact-based, and somewhat comprehensive research and discussion regarding the effects of kratom. It is clear; however, that substantially more scientific research needs to be done, especially regarding possibly dangerous prescription drug interactions involving kratom, in order to allow medical professionals and the general public to make educated and responsible decisions regarding the use of kratom for various ailments. It is my sincere hope that the DEA acts deliberately and without haste- fully considering all input and thoroughly analyzing all available evidence, while resisting any potentially biased influence from pharmaceutical companies or grieving mothers, before making an objective, fact-based decision regarding the legal status of a plant that many (veterans, students, business executives, soccer-moms, etc...) American citizens rely on for maintaining their quality of life. 

Sincerely,

Garrett T. Wissbaum

documents.commentText:
Please don't place Kratom as a schedule 1 drug. This natural plant helps many people safely cope with anxiety, recover from opiate addition and relieve symptoms of depression. It has been proven safe by hundreds of years of use.
The National Forensic Laboratory Information System, the DEA database that collects information from forensic labs throughout the country shows kratom appears in just a fraction of one percent of all reports for substances in 2013 (173 times) and 2014 (137 times). Contrast that with an over the counter pain reliever like acetaminophen (the main ingredient in Tylenol) which sends 78,000 people to the Emergency Room each year.
Kratom is non-habit forming, unless taken in high doses for extended periods of time. Users may experience dependence (similar to caffeine dependence) and discomfort on stopping excessive, daily use abruptly. Taken in excess it will cause nausea and vomiting; its own built-in safety mechanism.
Placing Kratom as a schedule 1 drug will do a tremendous disservice to the American public and only worsen the current war on drugs.

To Whom It May Concern, 

I am writing today to share my personal, albeit limited, experience with kratom for which I use strictly for pain relief. I say limited experience because I only recently discovered kratom during a quest for an alternative to opioid pain medication, which I have been prescribed for nearly three solid years. I do live in a state where medical marijuana is legal, but it is costly and requires time to obtain (I have many doctor appointments as it is). I also do not like the side effects from smoked marijuana and, until recently, edibles and alternative forms were not available to medical marijuana patients in my state. After doing some research on kratom I decided to give it a try and I am not exaggerating when I say it was nothing short of a god send for me. Let me tell you my story.

I am a 38 year old woman born and raised in the great state of Michigan. I grew up in a middle class family and went to public schools where I graduated with honors and was a member of the National Honor Society. I earned an Associate's Degree in Business from a community college and graduated Magna Cum Laude. I've worked since the age of 14, starting out as a Subway Sandwich Artist and landed in a Customer Service role around the age of 21 and I am still in that field today as a CSR Trainer. Also around the age of 21, I was officially diagnosed with Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS). A brief description of HS is that is an inflammatory condition which may be auto-immune related and causes painful abscesses, typically in the armpit, groin, back and abdomen. There are different stages and patients with HS can have varying degrees of severity. It is chronic. There is no cure, there is very little known about its cause and no consistent treatment...what works for one person may not work at all for the next. Many patients will have multiple surgeries, numbering into the hundreds. The best an HS patient can hope for is remission. I have yet to reach that point. 

Over the years since my diagnosis my symptoms have become progressively worse. I have severe lesions in my armpits and groin, continuous abscesses with tunneling and scarring. They are constant, they are numerous, and they are extraordinarily painful. The abscesses vary in size from that of a pea to as large as a lemon. They can become infected in which case the pain level is magnified exponentially. I've had a surgical consult. The prognosis is that I may lose all range of motion of my arms with no guarantee that the surgery will be successful in preventing recurrence. Every day activities are painful for me, starting with the simplest of tasks...like getting dressed. Therefore I've been prescribed anti-inflammatory medications (ibuprofen) and opioid pain medication. 

With all of the recent publicity of opioid addiction, overdoses, and fatalities; naturally, I've become concerned about the long term use of narcotics. Also, there are harmful side effects to consider, such as liver damage, kidney disease, and heart disease from long term use of ibuprofen. I needed to find an alternative and I found one, kratom. From the first use I was astounded. The relief was almost immediate after ingesting a relatively small amount (about one and a half teaspoons mixed with juice). I haven't experienced any negative side effects, beyond the awful taste. I don't experience any dizziness, nauseousness, or sleepiness as I sometimes do with the opioid pain medicine. It doesn't always get rid of the pain, there are times when I still need the opioids; but since I discovered kratom I've been able to significantly reduce my use of prescription pain meds and ibuprofen. And I can function completely after taking kratom; there is no impairment like there can be with opioids. 

When I learned that the DEA was seeking to classify kratom as a schedule I narcotic I was deeply dismayed. I'm only one person but I know how much it has helped me and to classify this plant, a cousin to coffee, as a dangerous narcotic with no medical potential is short-sighted and arbitrary. It needs to be studied and researched and a schedule I classification will make it extremely difficult, if not impossible to do so. I urge you, I implore you...table this emergency classification and allow the scientific and medical community to continue its work regarding kratom. Discovering kratom was life changing for me; I know I'm not the only one. The community of Americans suffering chronic debilitating diseases deserve for every, and any, potential treatment to be fully examined. Thank you.

I believe I also sustained some injuries in my neck that weren't as severe,  but I don't have the extra money to get more MRIs and costly regulard doctors visits to find out.  At such a young age,  the doctors all wanted me to take narcotic pain killers workout having any long term solutions to deal with the pain, other than surgeries that have many potential risks and more drugs. I was adamantly against the idea of relying on drugs for any extended period, but after a few years the constant pain caused me to eventually give in to their recommendations. After only a few months I experienced myriad of negative effects ranging from depression to lethargy and mood swings,  along with feeling the need to take them regularly.  I stopped taking them shortly thereafter because I felt it becoming extremely detrimental to my overall wellbeing. I dealt with the pain for a few more years until being introduced to kratom by a naturopath doctor.  The first time I took it I felt such relief it was amazing.  It didn't cause any impairment or lethargy,  I just felt relief and almost a bit of energy.  It has made such a positive difference in my life and my ability to be productive and work harder without pain than I'd been to in a long time with no side effects,  I can't imagine why anyone would ever want to make such a miraculous plant illegal. I've consumed it when necessary on a regular basis for the past 5 years with no ill effect, I've had my liver and kidney function along with all my blood levels tested yearly and my doctor has seem morning but improvement in my overall health.  Everyone I've ever shared it with reported nothing but positive results (including my elderly grandmother,  who was a drug rehab councilor  for most of my life) and I've personally seen it help people with everything from fibromyalgia pain to PTSD stress/anxiety.  If you take this plant away, thousand and thousands of people will be adversely effected.  They aren't kids or drug addicts looking to get high (you can't get high from it, if you over consume it, you will become nauseous and most likely throw it up in a sort of self regulating fashion), they are everyday people,  a lot of which are very productive members of society and you'll do them immeasurable harm by talking away this amazing natural herbal remedy. These are my heartfelt thoughts and I hope you take them under serious consideration.

documents.commentText:
I suffer from Syringomyelia (a progressive degenerative spinal disorder that produces pain, weakness and numbness in the limbs). The condition is generally treated with opiate drugs and surgery. Since my initial diagnosis 7 years ago, I have been on several rounds of drugs including Neurontin (gabapentin) and Tegretol (carbamazepine) as well as Oxycontin. All of these drugs have profound side-effects and great potential for abuse and addiction. In my search for more effective, less addictive treatments, I began using kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) extract. To me, it has been a blessing! Brewed in a tea or taken in extract form, it is no more addictive than a cup of coffee and has almost zero side effects. It effectively kills pain without impairment of any kind. The only side-effect I have noticed, based upon long experience with this plant, is nausea or vomiting if one takes too much (an effect which makes "recreational use" of this substance in high doses frankly ridiculous--unless projectile vomiting is somehow cool now?). 

When used correctly, the plant is well-tolerated, essentially non-toxic and highly effective. So naturally, the DEA needs to ban it? As a sufferer of chronic pain, I can tell you that would be a tremendous mistake! As an American, I cannot help but reject the DEA's war upon Nature as it attempts to declare yet another plant illegal as it has done with marijuana (another plant whose medical benefits are now well-known). It is not in the purview of any government agency to determine how something that can be found growing in your own garden can be used by a citizen. In other words, one does not ban grapes because they can be made into wine which can then go on to have adverse effects in the world. This concept is called "freedom." I note the DEA has never moved to ban tobacco (a substance with proven detrimental effects on the body), neither would I suggest it do so despite the overwhelming evidence to that effect. Why? Because if people choose to smoke tobacco they should be free to do so. There's a warning label on the product indicating the negative health effects. That should be the limit (along with some common sense measures to protect people from second hand smoke) of the government's involvement in this. Or is the DEA's real agenda here to keep people like me dependent on Big Pharma's expensive and dangerous remedies?

Your submission guidelines say I should give factual accounts and scientific evidence to support my views. I could well ask: How much scientific review has the DEA done on this or frankly almost any drug it has seen fit to ban in the public interest? Apparently little to none. So just to review, if alcohol (which killed 88,000 people last year) is legal and cigarettes (which kill approximately half a million Americans every year) are legal then kratom (which has killed no one) should stay legal and available. There has not been a single case of kratom by itself causing a death when not mixed with other substances. I'm frankly surprised that that simple fact has escaped the notice of the DEA, but perhaps I shouldn't be. After all the DEA does have a long history of ignoring well-established medical facts, as in the case of marijuana or even LSD (an alkaloid which was used quite successfully to treat chronic alcoholism and as an adjunct to psychotherapy for decades before it was capriciously banned by the same agency that would deprive people like me of virtually the only effective treatment for my particular condition). If any of what I have said about the history and medical benefits of any drug I have mentioned herein (cannabinoid or alkaloid) strike the reader as strange, then such a reader has either a) no experience with the substances in question or b) no knowledge of them. In either case, such a reader should not be in the position to make policy on such substances, plain and simple. Yet, the ignorance contained in the DEA's proposed ban demonstrates profound lack of knowledge and experience. One is forced to question the wisdom of an agency that would permit the sale and consumption of truly toxic and dangerous substances (because it fears the economic backlash from a ban on such substances) but would ban a plant that, like marijuana, has never been shown to be toxic when taken by itself.

Therefore, on this scientific basis and for the benefit of everyone that uses this plant for pain relief and overall health and well-being, I urge you to dismiss this proposed ban.

Kratom is one of the most amazing plants on this Earth. It is completely natural, has been used for over 2000 years, and by containing natural alkaloids it can help reduce pain and help ween people off of prescription opiates. People die every day from opiate overdoses prescribed by doctors who think they are doing people a favor and then these people become addicted to these drugs. Kratom is non-addictive, and even when people with addictive personalities use more than an average person would, it is never in excess because no one has ever overdosed on Kratom.
Banning the plant because pharmaceutical companies want a monopoly on certain alkaloids is protecting an industry and wants Americans to become addicted so they keep making money. 
I use Kratom, not because I am an opiate addict or have chronic pain, but as a mood elevator much like coffee. A small amount will make me focused and slightly energetic which helps me be more active, and therefore healthier, and also more focused on the job I am doing. I am fully in support of it and only wish that more research be done on this plant so we can help as many of our fellow Americans as we can.
